data.meta_description: Commissioned to make a propaganda film about the 1936 Olympic Games in Germany, director Leni Riefenstahl created a celebration of the human form. This first half of her two-part film opens with a renowned introduction that compares modern Olympians to classical Greek heroes, then goes on to provide thrilling in-the-moment coverage of some of the games' most celebrated moments, including African-American athlete Jesse Owens winning a then-unprecedented four gold medals.

Olympia Part I: Festival of the Nations is the first film which documents the 1936 Summer Olympics hosted in Berlin in a new 100,000 capacity stadium which Adolf Hitler had built for the occasion.

He invited German propagandist and Nazi sympathiser Leni Riefenstahl to document the tournament, mainly on the strength of her filmed account of the Nazi Party's 1934 Nuremberg rallies. She resultantly produced a great sports symphony, the innovations of which has influenced all subsequent sports coverage.
